newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: South Korea to raise energy prices - minister.
newsitem.headline: South Korea to raise energy prices - minister.

text.p: South Korea will raise energy prices in an attempt to cut rising energy consumption, Trade, Industry and Energy Minister Lim Chang-yeul said on Thursday.
"We'll readjust energy prices to the levels of other non oil-producing countries," Lim told a news conference.
A ministry official said South Korea's energy prices are relatively cheap compared to those of other countries that do not produce oil.
The official said the ministry could raise gas and electricity prices and also increase taxes on oil products.
The South Korean government has liberalised oil product prices.
From January 1, domestic prices of gasoline, kerosene, diesel and C-type fuel were deregulated and no longer subject to a government-set monthly price ceiling.
Lim's announcement came at a time when rising energy demand has been a big factor in the nation's spiralling trade deficit.
